eventName: In memory of Graham Philip Clough
story:
Graham passed away peacefully on New Year's Day following a brain haemorrhage, which happened suddenly a few days earlier whilst asleep. He had been relatively fit and healthy over Christmas and had enjoyed a bike ride on Christmas Day and was taken too soon, which was an enormous shock to us, our family and friends. We had been married for more than 30 years and myself, our son James, and the family have been able to support each other over the holidays whilst Graham was in hospital. 

Graham was a Chartered Surveyor until he retired at the end of 2012 and had enjoyed an active life, including being a referee for the children's football league, running marathons for charity fund-raising, bike riding, football and other outdoor activities. Graham also loved painting and had completed a few pictures over the years. He was an avid Leeds United fan and also enjoyed his horseracing and loved to socialise. Graham's ethos in life was that 'life was for living' and will be greatly missed by his family and friends.   

Please donate in lieu of funeral flowers to either ICU who took good care of him and supported us at Calderdale Hospital or British Heart Foundation. 

Death leaves a heartache no one can heal, but love leaves a memory no can steal.

story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. In previous years, the BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK. This year, however, Covid-19 has put people with heart and circulatory conditions at a greater risk than ever. The effects of the virus have also cut BHF's ability to fund new life saving research in half. 

  • £10 could pay for a toolkit used by heart attack researchers. 
  • £20 could provide an hour of vital support from a Helpline Cardiac Nurse. 
  • £25 could pay for on hour of research by BHF early career scientists. 
  • £50 could help fund a training kit which allows more people to learn CPR. 
  • £100 help train a PhD student starting their career in research. 

It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. Every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. 

Myself and my colleagues, both at Adecco and SWR, will be working together to reach 1 Million Steps in February to help raise awareness and funds for the British Heart Foundation. 

Thanks for your support!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge British Heart Foundation have faced in their 60 year history. It led to them being forced to make the devastating decision to cut their 2020 research budget in half. They've never needed people like us more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox is a way to help them keep up the pace of progress. My willpower to give up sweets, chocolate and fizzy drinks will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need British Heart Foundation most. 

Despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - BHF can't drop the ball now.

This is my third year doing the Dechox and this year I have stepped it up a notch as there is now the option to give up more than just chocolate, as of the 1st March 2021 I am giving up all things sweet and fizzy drinks. During this time and being stuck at home it's easy to reach for the snacks and pig out, I mean there's nothing better to do right?...Wrong! Rather than pigging out, I want to benefit the charity closest to my heart by raising this money, all I am asking for is support and even the smallest donation will go towards saving lives. My aim is to raise £300.00 and in the past I've absolutely smashed this so I am hoping this year along with all your help and support I will smash it again.

Let's do this!

Thank you all to those in advance who will support me, it really means the world to me.

story: This is the 3rd year I will have supported the BHF by joining in their charity Dechox. Anybody who knows me well will know that there are very few days when I don't have some type of chocolate, I guess I am a bit of an addict!!! . So you will know how hard this challenge is going to be for me. BHF is struggling more this year than ever before, because of the dreaded covid 19 pandemic, many of their charity shops have had to close, many of their main fundraising events have also had to be cancelled due to lockdown. Quite a lot of my family and friends have been unfortunate to have had problems with their hearts and I'm sure without the important research funded by this charity some of them would definitely not be here now, myself included, as without an operation on my heart when I was a child I would probably not be here now. I would be so grateful if once again you could find it in your "hearts" to donate some money to this worthwhile cause. However small you think the donation is, it will all be very much appreciated and used to continue funding important research and work. Thanks you so much in anticipation. Xx

story:
In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Throughout the globe Covid-19 has spread rapidly. We are very lucky enough to have first class healthcare service and government support in this crisis. Unfortunately others around the world are not so lucky. In an attempt to give back to those in need this February Justin Graetz and team has set themselves a challenge to run 300km each throughout the month (averaging over 10km a day) in order to raise money for UNICEF. UNICEF, also known as the united nations children’s fund, is a United Nations agency responsible for providing humanitarian and developmental aid to children worldwide. 

We extend the invitation to anyone who would like to join us on our ‘Rona Run’ or set your own challenge for the month and help support those in need!
